item.title: Who Handled My Signal?
item.description:
I’ve written a fair share of signal handlers in my life, some good and some worse. This time I didn’t even have to write one, but I still managed to mess it up.

Blocking signals and a systemd event loop

I was working on an application written in c++, running on an embedded system. On the embedded system my application had to use some IPC (Inter Process Communication) and the system had support for dbus communication. So I decided to run the application using the systemd event loop. To exit the event loop, and thus shutting down the process, you just had to let the systemd event loop handle the SIGTERM. For a proper introduction to the sd-event-loop I suggest reading Lennart Poetterings blog post on the subject.

To not let the default signal handler (that all signals have) step in and handle the signal, you add a block on the desired signals with the help of sigprocmask(). Then you create a new signal event source and adds it to the event loop: All this is done with the help of sd_event_add_signal(). Here follows an example implementing a simple application, listening on the signal SIGINT (interrupt, i.e. Ctrl-C) with the help of the systemd event loop.

#include <systemd/sd-daemon.h>
#include <systemd/sd-event.h>
#include "spdlog/spdlog.h"
#include "spdlog/async.h"
#include "spdlog/sinks/basic_file_sink.h"
#include <cstring>

int signal_handler(sd_event_source* es, const struct signalfd_siginfo* si, void* /*userdata*/) {
    spdlog::info("Signal handler: Got {}", strsignal(si->ssi_signo));
    sd_event_exit(sd_event_source_get_event(es), 0);
    return 0;
}

bool SetupSignalHandler(sd_event* event) {
    sigset_t ss;
    // Exclude all signals from defined signal set (ss)
    if (sigemptyset(&ss) < 0) {
        return false;
    }
    // Add SIGINT to signal sets
    if (sigaddset(&ss, SIGINT) < 0) {
        return false;
    }
    // Add signal mask to calling thread.
    // SIGINT is now blocked in this thread.
    if (sigprocmask(SIG_BLOCK, &ss, nullptr) < 0) {
        return false;
    }
    // Let the sd event loop handle SIGINT
    if (sd_event_add_signal(event, nullptr, SIGINT, signal_handler, nullptr) < 0) {
        return false;
    }
    return true;
}

int main() {
    sd_event* event = nullptr;
    auto logfile = spdlog::basic_logger_mt<spdlog::async_factory>(
    		"file_logger", "logs/log.txt");

    // Acquire default event loop object (for calling thread).
    int event_loop_aquired = sd_event_default(&event);
    if (event_loop_aquired < 0) {
        logfile->critical("Acquiring event loop failed");
        return EXIT_FAILURE;
    }

    if (!SetupSignalHandler(event)) {
        logfile->critical("Failed to setup signal handler");
        return EXIT_FAILURE;
    }

    spdlog::info("Application started");
    int event_loop_exit_code = sd_event_loop(event);
    spdlog::info("Application is shutting down");
    if (event_loop_exit_code < 0) {
        logfile->critical("Bad event loop exit code: {d}", event_loop_exit_code);
        return EXIT_FAILURE;
    }

    if (event_loop_aquired >= 0) {
        sd_event_unref(event);
    }

    return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

Apart from the systemd stuff, I also added spdlog to simplify and prettify the logging part.

Looks pretty sweet, but I should probably check that it does what I hope it does.

Console output:

[2020-07-02 21:24:40.564] [info] Application started
^C

Okey, that didn’t go as expected. This sd_event_loop doesn’t seem to work at all as expected. What could possibly be the problem here? It looks like signals default handler goes in and handles the application shutdown even though it is clearly blocked. A wise friend of mine said that I should inspect my process SigBlk (signal block) in /proc. A place where you can find details regarding your running processes.

❯ ps -a
PID TTY          TIME CMD
15646 pts/1    00:00:00 nvim
16441 pts/20   00:00:00 event_loop
16443 pts/21   00:00:00 ps

There we have it, our event_loop running with PID 16441. Let’s inspect it further.

❯ cat /proc/16441/status
Name: event_loop
Umask:  0002
State:  S (sleeping)
......
......
CoreDumping:  0
Threads:  2
SigQ: 0/31666
SigPnd: 0000000000000000
ShdPnd: 0000000000000000
SigBlk: 0000000000000002
SigIgn: 0000000000000000
.....
.....

I had a look, and sure, it looked good. My process had SigBlk: 0000000000000002 which corresponds to block SIGINT, which was my intent (great post on stackoverflow on how to interpret SigBlk). So why isn’t it blocked? And why is it handled by the default signal handler?

The same friend then said, make sure you don’t have any process threads that don’t have the same mask. “Yeah, my application only has one thread", was my response. That was a lie. But in my defence, I didn’t know it was a lie, I just had no idea.

If you have a look in the output above, you can actually see that the process has two threads, it clearly says so: Threads: 2, but sometimes your blind. This has to be some other issue, I thought to myself.

Eventually I ran out of ideas. I stripped everything in the code apart from my custom signal handler and the sd_event_loop. To my relief and surprise the handler worked. Maybe there is a possibilty another thread is spawned in the original solution after all. I followed my friends advice and had a look at the process tasks, now running with the original solution again.

❯ ls /proc/16441/task
16441  16442

Oh shit, there we have it. Our process spawns another thread. Let’s inspect the spawned threads SigBlk.

❯ cat /proc/16441/task/16442/status
Name: event_loop
Umask:  0002
State:  S (sleeping)
......
......
CoreDumping:  0
Threads:  2
SigQ: 0/31666
SigPnd: 0000000000000000
ShdPnd: 0000000000000000
SigBlk: 0000000000000000
SigIgn: 0000000000000000
.....
.....

I believe we just found out who handled my signal, it was dear old 16442.

The solution

You may have guessed who spawned the new thread. Of course it was the fancy logging library that I use.

The function: spdlog::basic_logger_mt<spdlog::async_factory>(...) spawns a new thread and since it is called before sigprocmask is used to block SIGINT the child thread has no idea that it shouldn’t handle the incoming SIGINT.

What in gods name is this guy doing, you may have asked yourself. In my defence, this is a greatly simplified implementation of the actual code I wrote.

If I were to summarazise this post in two sentences it would be:

What happens when a thread is spawned? It inherits its parents SigBlk. If parents SigBlk is later updated, the child will have no idea about it.

Fair enough, the hard part is knowing that a thread has been spawned if you explicitly don’t do it yourself. So, how should the code look like? One easy fix would be to avoid the funtion call spdlog::basic_logger_mt<spdlog::async_factory>(...) and use the basic, non async one that doesn’t spawn a new thread. That wouldn’t be very educational though.

What I’ve learned is that when a thread is created, it inherits its parents SigBlk. So the straight forward approach would be to add the signal block before the child thread is spawned.

...
...
...

int main() {
    if (!SetupSignalBlock(event)) {
        return EXIT_FAILURE;
    }

    sd_event* event = nullptr;
    // New thread spawned
    auto logfile = spdlog::basic_logger_mt<spdlog::async_factory>("file_logger", "logs/log.txt");

    // Acquire default event loop object (for calling thread).
    int event_loop_aquired = sd_event_default(&event);
    if (event_loop_aquired < 0) {
        logfile->critical("Acquiring event loop failed");
        return EXIT_FAILURE;
    }

    // Let the sd event loop handle SIGINT
    if (sd_event_add_signal(event, nullptr, SIGINT, signal_handler, nullptr) < 0) {
        return false;
    }

    ...

    return EXIT_SUCCESS;
}

Let’s run the application! Now it looks a bit more like I expected.

[2020-07-03 21:24:14.146] [info] Application started</samp><br>
^C[2020-07-03 21:24:16.637] [info] Signal handler: Got Interrupt
[2020-07-13 21:24:16.637] [info] Application is shutting down

So, trust your friends, keep track of your threads, and know that you always can inspect your process status under /proc.

Further reading

  • GNU C library reference manual: 24 Signal Handling
  • Linux Filesystem Hierarchy: /proc

item.title: unordered_map vs. map (with an unordered focus)
item.description:
Why am prone to using std::unordered_map over std::map?

It all comes down to performance. The map is normally implemented as a binary search tree and thus resulting in a worst case search time of O(log n), which is great.

The worst case search time for the unordered_map is O(n). So why do I prefer it? Because the unordered_map is implemented as a hash table and the average search time for the unordered_map is constant, i.e. O(1).

If your data needs to stay in a specific order, the unordered_map is not the way to go. It is almost like you can hear it on its name. Also, the unordered_map generally use more memory, and inserting and removing elements can be slower compared to the regular map. For lookups, the unordered_map is outstanding.

If we lift the hood of the unordered_map, what would we find? Of course that depends on the compiler, but most likely a vector containing buckets. So what is bucket now? From cppreference:

“A bucket is a slot in the container’s internal hash table to which elements are assigned based on the hash value of their key”.

When doing a lookup, your key is hashed, and the hashed value will point you to a bucket. The bucket most likely contain a linked list with all elements whose hashed key value corresponds to that bucket.

Here is an illustration I made using the bucket example:

std::unordered_map<std::string,std::string> mymap = {
    {"us","United States"},
    {"uk","United Kingdom"},
    {"fr","France"},
    {"de","Germany"}
};

When the number of elements in the unordered_map equals or exceeds the number of buckets, the unordered_map is resized. The reason is to avoid the linked list to become to large, which would result in worse performance. This is what is called the load balance.

When the elements and the number of buckets are equal, the load balance is 1.0. When the load balance exceeds 1.0 the table needs to be rehashed, which is costly. That would partly explain why inserting elements can be slower compared to the traditional map.

In the example above, the load balance would be: 4 elements/5 buckets = 0.8

With some imagination you can conclude that the lower the load balance, the lower the probability that several elements end up in the same bucket. Thus lowering the average search time.

item.title: Sort anything with std::sort and a comparator
item.description:
This is part of the advent of code posts, so the puzzles referred can be viewed at https://adventofcode.com/2020

For the day 5 part 2 puzzle I read the description a bit too fast (again). I thought I had to give the “binary space partitioning seat id” as the answer. So when I answered "BBFFBBFRLL" both me and the Advent of code website was a bit confused.

I stopped what I was doing and read the instructions carefully and answered 524. Now everyone was happy.

In my solution I used std::sort on all the set IDs and then went through the result to see where the gap was. Before I found the more simple solution I used std::sort with the boarding pass strings and a lambda function comparing the results. As I found out, it wasn’t useful but at least I learnt something.

This is how I used it:

std::vector<std::string> boarding_passes =
        CreateVectorFromFile("input.txt");
std::sort(boarding_passes.begin(), boarding_passes.end(),
          [] (std::string s1, std::string s2) {
                return (GetSeatId(s1) < GetSeatId(s2));
           });

Deep down I knew about this, but I had never tried it. As long as you can produce a predicate from comparing the items in the list. The result when printing the now sorted boarding_passes:

Result:

...
BFBBBBBRRL
BFBBBBBRRR
BBFFFFFLLL
BBFFFFFLLR
BBFFFFFLRL
BBFFFFFLRR
BBFFFFFRLL
...

item.title: Parsing text with regex in c++
item.description:
Part of a series of posts I wrote after participating in the advent of code challenge

Parsing text is a skill every developer should have in its tool belt, for the simple reason that it is one of the most common tasks in this field. I have done quite a lot of parsing in my days, but never in c++.

Parsing strings in c++ is unfortunatly not as intuitive as in for example python, but with the standard libraries you have access to some powerful tools.

For the advent of code, it was the day 4 challenge that convinced me to improve my regex game.

Regex

The most simple basics that gets me up to speed with regex:

^: match beginning of string

$: match end of string

(): defines the part of the string that you will get as a match when calling regex_search(line, match, regex)

{number}: pattern match with range or exact number.

I know there are more simple basics that would be good to always remember, but I think this a great start.

An example in c++

On day 4 of the advent of code challenge you should verify that the input followed a certain pattern. I will use the hair color part as an example.

The input could look like the following:

hcl:#cfa07d

and should follow the pattern defined as:

hcl (Hair Color) - a # followed by exactly six characters 0-9 or a-f.

For this example we just need to see that an input matches a specific pattern. The regex for the “pattern defined” is:

hcl:#([a-f0-9]{6})

Meaning, the string should start with hcl:# followed by exacly 6 characters ranging from a-f and 0-9.

#include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <regex>

void printHclValidity(const std::string& hcl) {
    const std::regex matcher = std::regex("hcl:#([a-f0-9]{6})");
    const bool valid = std::regex_match(hcl, matcher);
    if (valid) {
        std::cout << "Valid!\n";
    } else {
        std::cout << "Invalid: " << hcl.c_str() << "\n";
    }
}

int main() {
    std::string example_hcl = "hcl:#cfa07d";
    std::string too_long_hcl = "hcl:#cfa077d";
    std::string invalid_character_hcl = "hcl:#c!a07d";
    printHclValidity(example_hcl);
    printHclValidity(too_long_hcl);
    printHclValidity(invalid_character_hcl);
}

The snippet above will give the following output compiled with c++17

Valid!
Invalid: hcl:#cfa077d
Invalid: hcl:#c!a07d

https://regex101.com/ is a great website for testing out your regexes on sample data.

item.title: Reading file input in C++
item.description:
This is part of a series of articles I wrote after taking part in the advent of code challenge.

All of the problems were dependent on some input, and for the sake of keeping the code clean I put the input in a text file outside of the source code. Day two I stumbled over this stackoverflow post regarding reading from an input file and it has been a part of almost all the solutions.

std::ifstream is(input_filename);
std::string line;
while (std::getline(is, line)) {
	// parse line by line and create data structure.
}

This gave me a great way of handling every line in the provided input.

I could stop here. This was enough for reading the inputs for the 6 challenges I battled, but I was a bit curios to go a bit deeper, and try understand what is actually going on when creating a std::ifstream and looping over it with std::getline. Like how does it work really, you have the input file, which basically is some amount of bytes in memory (like everything else), and with one object creation and a function we can go through each line in that file. I have some intuition on how it probably works, but I think if I studied the mechanics of the ifstream object it would be a bit more clear.

From cppreference.com we can read that:

“ifstream implements high-level input operations on file-based streams”.

cplusplus.com explains the std::ifstream like this:

“Objects of this class maintain a filebuf object as their internal stream buffer, which performs input/output operations on the file they are associated with (if any).”

So if we would like to implement our own ifstream, it could look something like this (non template version):

class ifstream : public istream {
	ifstream();
  ...
  private:
  std::filebuf internal_stream_buffer;
}

Where std::filebuf is a specialization defined in header <streambuf>: basic_filebuf<char>.

The created std::filebuf object needs to be associated to a file by calling member open. So for our implementation of ifstream to work with the one line in my advent of code solutions the constructor needs to call open on the internal_stream_buffer.

Remember, this is only my simple implementation, in the std libraries ifstream, the filename is optional and you can call open later, after the object is created.

ifstream::ifstream(std::string filename) {
	internal_stream_buffer.open(filename);
}

ifstream::~ifstream() {
  internal_stream_buffer.close();
}

That is how the tip of the iceberg would look. How does this work with the std::getline function then?

“getline reads characters from an input stream and places them into a string.”

If we were to implement our own simple, let’s call it nonstd::getline(). It could look like this:

namespace nonstd {
ifstream& getline(ifstream& input, std::string& str) {
	str.clear();
	char c;
	while (input.get(c) && ch != '\n') {
		str.push_back(c);
  }
  return input;
} 
}

When getline is done, both the ifstream and string objects passed as references has changed (if characters where found). The ifstream object is changed in the regard that a complete line is now extracted. So when we call getline on the same object the next time, it will not have the extracted line anymore and thus getting the next line. The str object is changed and filled with characters, if any where found before encountering the newline (’\n')

Of course you can go deeper than this for a more thorough understanding, but that can be the topic for another post, since I think that hole is quite deep.

item.title: Advent of Code
item.description:
I’ve heard about advent of code previous years but have never taken part. This year I decided to try and join in on as many challenges as my schedule allowed. I can prance with 12 points and 6 challenges fulfilled as of 15 days in to December.

Unfortunately I think this will be it for me. The challenges are fun, but I’m missing some sort of performance evaluation. Right now it is all about just finishing the challenges as quickly as possible when released, and no focus on who does the most elegant or effective solution. On the other hand, maybe that is the charm, just focusing on solving the problems with no performance anxiety.

In the upcoming days I will compile some blog posts on what I have learned.

The posts compiled after this post:

  1. Reading file input in c++
  2. Parsing text with regex in c++
  3. Sort anything with std::sort and a comparator

All of my six solutions are present on github
